bio: Author, food blogger, food photography, travel, chiaroscuro South Devon U.K. Feedfeed editor Next workshops/ London, Australia, Scotland, India

posts.description: My partner and I baked these @lily_vanilli_cake brownies yesterday from her book sweet tooth they are soooo good (the best we have ever had) we are about to have one now with a cuppa

Wish I still had some of this cake it was really yummy next time I'm going to try making it into a ginger cake rather than a lemon cake as the texture reminded me of a Jamaican ginger cake, I used avocado instead of butter and palm sugar but I made it like a Genoese sponge so I whipped the eggs and sugar to get the volume then added the flour and finally the avocado, I mashed the avocado with the lemon juice so it was really smooth

KERALA workshop pre registration, you know how much I love Kerala (this recipe was inspired by my trip there) and I am happy to announce that @boxofspice and I are holding our second workshop there between the 11/15 of August the workshop will be a food photography yoga retreat, we are combining the two because you can't go to south India and not do yoga can you? Kerala is a beautiful part of India and our resort is situated right on the famous backwaters. We are offering 10% off for people who book now before we open the registration. India is one of the countries that I feel changes you when you visit, In a good way, it makes you feel so many things. I have been lucky enough to visit three times and two of those where for workshops with @boxofspice and we are pleased to announce we have another planned for September and this time it’s a really special one as we are going to be staying in Hampi. It is known for its incredible ruins from the 14th century and breath taking landscapes. This photo of the rains I took last time I was in India when we held the workshop in Kerala I think captures India’s beautiful spirit. To find out more follow the link in the stories I have just added I will save them to my highlights. I hope you can join us

Not long until I head back to India with @boxofspice for the next retreat this time in Kerala there are still some spots available details are on my blog. This photos was taken at our last workshop in coorg we had a dinner on the deck of this cabin that was situated in the middle of a coffee plantation we had our meals cooked and served only by candle light, it was one of the most amazing dining experiences of my life. I can't wait to see what we get to do on our next workshop

The rolling tea hills in munnar is one of my favourite places I have ever visited, it's high up in the clouds and everywhere you look there is breath taking views of all the tea plantations (that is a cloud not mist!). I travelled there with my grandma last year. My grandparents travelled all over the world together. She always wanted to go to Kerala but my grandad struggled with his health in the end and they couldn't go to places with high altitude any more as it affected his breathing too much. After he passed away I found her looking at a lone traveller brochure and I said hell no! Your not going on your own I will go with you. So we decided to go together. It was such a great trip and we have booked our next adventure in November for china and I can't wait.

I always joke that I must of been Italian in a previous life.

I'm sharing my favourite mushroom dish to raise awareness of Ghiras Al Nahda - a crowd-funding project that teaches locals how to grow mushrooms and feed families in war-torn Syria.
100% of all funds raised go to those who need it most, head to humanitarian crowd-funding platform www.candoaction.org to get involved, plus share your favourite mushroom dish @CanDo_Action
My favourite mushroom dish is creamy garlic mushroom pizza with pancetta and cream cheese
pizza base

175g ’00’ or plain flour
1 tbsp olive oil
½ tsp fast-action dried yeast
½ tsp salt
120 ml water (lukewarm)
Put the flour, yeast and salt into a large bowl (or mixer) – Put the salt and yeast on opposite sides of the bowl to prevent the salt killing the yeast. Make a well in the centre and add half the water (60ml) and the oil, mix well. Keep adding water a little bit at a time until all of the flour has been incorporated into the dough. The dough should be slightly sticky but not to wet. knead with the dough hook or on an oiled surface for about 5 minutes. place dough in a oiled bowl and leave to rise for about 1 to 1 and a half hours until doubled in size.

preheat oven to 200c fan

topping

1 cup spinach
2 garlic cloves
1/4 cup pine nuts
1/3 cup grated parmesan
2 tbsp. oil
salt and pepper
3/4 cup cream cheese like Philadelphia
5 slices or pancetta
4 large mushrooms
hand full of pine nuts
half a leek sliced thinly
1 mozzarella cheese shredded
handful of spinach
salt and pepper
make the pesto add the spinach, garlic cloves, parmesan and pine nuts with a little oil in a food processer, add the cream cheese and mix,

knock out air in dough and stretch into a circle spread on the cream cheese mixture then top with sliced mushrooms, pancetta, pine nuts, spinach and mozzarella and leeks drizzle with a little oil and add salt and pepper bake for 15 to 20 minutes

Seaside walks today in Brixham, in South Devon where I live (I live in the next town along), it is a famous fishing village and where most of the seafood in the area is landed and where my brother dives for scallops. How lucky to live in such a lovely part of England I often forget.

I’m going to make this pumpkin sage and mascarpone risotto again for tea this week, to make it cook it as you would a normal risotto but add 4 chopped sage leaves with the onion then add rice and the wine, stock and at the end stir In cup of roasted pumpkin purée, half and cup of mascarpone and some grated Parmesan and top with crispy sage. It was so delicious. I always add a good drizzle of balsamic vinegar too and stir it in.

The dumpling production line yesterday, I thought I would do that a different shape than normal and cut the dough into squares like window wrappers. I tried them last night and they where really delicious. They where filled with smoked tofu, mushrooms, leek, kale and pak choi. I chopped it all really finely in a food processor and sautéed it all with some chopped chives, spring onions and soy sauce In a pan with some sesame oil first to enhance the flavour a bit. I think normally the fillings for dumplings go in raw but I like the flavour it adds from cooking it first even if it’s not necessarily the traditional way.

It’s the weekend, so that means I’m making pasta and slow cooked weekend sauce but this weekend I’m thinking about trying out my new pressure cooker, I was going to get an instant pot as they are so popular but most of my kitchen gadgets are from @sageappliances so I wanted it to match and saw they did a fast slow pot that seems to work just like the instant pot but it’s a bit better looking so I ordered that. I will let you know how it goes. I have never used a pressure cooker before or a slow cooker so it’s new territory to me but I’m hoping it will change the way I cook as some meals I make take 2 and a half hours in the oven so to be able to half that time or to be able to leave it all day and not worry about it would be great, do you have a pressure cooker or instant pot of similar ? I would love to hear what you use it for? I’m thinking Ragu, stew, curry ect. My partner is worried that using a pressure cooker will mean you won’t get all the flavour from slow cooking it in a cast iron pan in the oven, what is your experience with this ?, photo from my workshop with @the_social_kitchen the other week

I used the left over duck and made soup dumplings with it. I Boiled down the left over duck bones and skin and made the aspec and sautéed the left over meat with spring onions and some of the left over Sauce sooo yummy. I hadn’t realised what soup dumplings where until recently when I saw them on @xlbcr Stories and now I’m hooked. Basically when you make the bone stock and leave it in the fridge it gels so you can add it in the dumplings in chunks and when they are cooked it turned into a soupy broth again.

I put the recipe for these waffles

The easiest Christmas treat, all you need is 300ml double cream
300g good quality dark chocolate
50g unsalted butter
Finely chop the chocolate while heating the cream and butter in a pan once it’s reached the boil add the chopped chocolate and stir in and mix until the chocolate has melted now you have your truffle mixture, you can add some amaretto liqueur or baileys or what ever flavour you like (35ml) then leave it to harden in the fridge over night and then take scoops and roll into balls and roll in chopped almonds or cocoa powder.

I managed to get a quick shot of my blood orange and Marzipan loaf yesterday before the light went and we ate it all 🙊. I used some mahleb spice from @ottolenghi in the dough and filling it was delicious. I added marzipan and blood orange juice and the mahleb spice in a blender and mixed it into a paste and spread it on the dough and rolled it up. Then when it was cooked I drizzled blood orange icing all over it. When it cooked at bottom there was a crispy ring of marzipan where it had dripped out that was my favourite bit.

The other day I made this spicy Mexican chicken soup it was so yummy and really comforting. I love Mexican food and wish I could cook more of it maybe that should be my New Years resolution. Here is the recipe
1lt Chicken stock
2 tins of plum tomatoes
Heaped tbsp chipotle paste (plus more to taste)
1 heaped tsp cumin
1/2 ground coriander
1/2 dried oregano
1 tsp chilli flakes
1 tin of kidney beans
1 tin of sweet corn
1 tin of black beans
1 red pepper chopped
2 chicken breasts
1 onion (half finely chopped half cut into strips)
1 avocado
Sour cream
Fresh coriander
1 lime
1 tsp smoked salt
Radishes
Tortillas
Poach the chicken in a pan of boiling water for 12 minutes. Once cooked shred with a fork. For soup in a blender (I used my new @kitchenaid_uk blender) add the stock and tinned tomatoes and spices and oregano then add to a big pan with the finely chopped onion, pepper, and beans and sweet corn. Then add the smoked Salt and some pepper and try it to see if it needs more chilli. Add the chicken. Pour into bowls and top with sliced onion, radish and avocado and a spoon full of sour cream and some grated cheese then finish with some fried tortillas cut into strips and some fresh coriander. Squeeze over some lime juice and enjoy. For extra flavour I added a spoonful of salsa

I have been super busy and I haven't had a chance to do any Halloween recipes this year. And I found this image from the recipe I did last year. This is pan de muerto also know as dead bread or day of the dead bread and it Is made for the Mexican celebration “day of the dead” on the 1st/2nd of November. this sweet bread is eaten on the day or on the days leading up to the day of the dead and is left at alters and grave sites of deceased loved ones. the scull and bones are meant to represent ones who are lost and there is often a teardrop on the loaf that is meant to represent those who are left behind. I love learning about different cultures cooking traditions of you search my blog you will find the recipe

Wishing I had some more of this Christmas crumble every one loved it, it's really simple to make add some sliced apples, half a jar of mincemeat, zest of an orange and half a tsp of chopped stem ginger in a baking dish and mix in about 4 tbsp brown sugar then to make the crumble crush half a packet of ginger biscuits and sprinkle over the top with some chopped Brazil nuts and candied orange and place some dabs of butter on top and bake for 35 minutes, it was a winner in my house we ate it warm with cream. The dish is from @nomliving and little bowl from @anakerin_kanalondon

Turmeric dough for the spiced pear butter buns. It's so vibrant even with just a little turmeric powder. To make the pear butter I peeled 4 pears and cut them in half and drizzled over some maple syrup and 2 cinnamon sticks and roasted them until they where soft then I puréed them and put them in a pan with 3/4 cup golden caster sugar and 2 tsp cinnamon powder and 1 tsp vanilla paste and stirred over the heat until it thickened up, then I took it off the heat I stirred in 2 tbsp of butter. It is soooo good

I have just made this lebkuchen cookie cake for my dad with a little gelatine snow globe on top, he arrived from France last night and I asked what cake he wanted me to make for him and he said something like a lebkuchen cookie so that's what I did, I made the mix for the cookies but used self raising flour and folded in 3 beaten egg whites and then the yokes so it's like three layers of lebkuchen cookies. I tried the off cuts and it was just like the cookie but a bit looser texture perfect for cake I will share the recipe this week in time for Christmas

I read an article yesterday on @eater about how Instagram food is a lie and it made me wonder if you think this is true ? I often find my self in a trap of creating just for content so I have something so share! so I have decided to step out of the kitchen for a few days and gather my thoughts. Two days away from the kitchen and I already feel a bit better, I get stuck in a rut sometimes and run out of ideas or I find things get a bit repetitive and I find my photos bore me. Do you get like this? Nothing makes me happier than cooking for enjoyment like this pasta and that's what I want to share here on my feed, things that I have created with joy not with the stress of I have to make something because I don't have any thing to post. So full of ideas I am off to the super market with big plans for a great new protect

Looking through my camera roll and came across this photo from China, we stumbled Upon this little house after taking a wrong turn in the park and I thought it was so cute. I also learnt that In china a lot of houses are white with black roofs as it’s good ying and yang. Our guide told us that people often see a Feng Shui master each year who gives them tips on what colour cloths to wear for that year and what to do around the home. The Water element is represented by blue and black roof colors. According to Feng Shui A black house roof will create a constant flow of positive energy around a house. I find it so interesting. The best Feng Shui has water and mountains near by so that’s why a lot of Chinese homes have ponds or water features and rock gardens.

I made this delicious beef and ale stew with Herby cheese scones and it was a real hit! I used this @denbypottery cast iron pan which I love I have it in two colours. Here is the recipe
For the stew
• 500g braising steak
• 1 onion finely chopped
• 3 rashers of smoke bacon chopped into lardons
• 300g chopped carrots and swede
• 200g mushrooms finely chopped
• 320ml pale ale
• 350ml beef stock
• Tied bunch of herbs like sage, thyme and rosemary
• Good splash or Worchester sauce
• Salt and pepper
Preheat the oven to 180c. In a lidded cast iron pan brown the beef with a little olive oil then remove and set aside. Add the onion and sauté until soft then add the bacon and mushrooms and stir until the bacon is cooked. Deglaze the pan with the ale and add the beef stock. Add the carrots and swede and the tied herbs and put the beef back in. place the lid on and cook for one hour, stir well then put the lid back on and cook for another hour. Add 200ml hot water and mix. Now make the scones
To make the scones
• 350g self-raising flour, plus extra for dusting
• 1 tsp baking powder
• 120g cold butter diced
• 130ml milk
• 150g grated cheddar plus more for top.
• Chopped herbs, thyme, sage and rosemary
• salt, pepper
• splash of milk for brushing
rub together the butter and flour and baking powder then add the grated cheddar and herbs and mix then add some salt and pepper to season and add the milk and mix with a spoon. Flour the work top and tip out the mixture and add some more flour on top. Press down with your hands to flatten and cut out the scones with a cookie cutter and place on top of stew. Brush the tops with milk and add some more cheddar and some herbs and sprinkle over some pepper and salt. Bake for 30 minutes. Then enjoy it’s perfect for this cold weather

I also really loved seeing all the spice plantations too as we got into thekkady you could smell the cardamom in the air. And the end of the holiday in Trivandrum on the beach was amazing we saw fish eagles and helped the fishermen pull in their nets. Kerala and truly stolen a piece of my heart and I can't wait to go back.

The finished kiwi mint and lemon curd meringue tarts from the other day to make the curd I used 4 egg yolks, 4 kiwis blended and put through a sieve and the Juice and zest of a one lemon and 3/4 cups of sugar with about 10 mint leaves (blend with kiwis and lemon juice until smooth) add to a pan and stir constantly over a medium heat until this thickens and coats the back of the spoon. then pour into a bowl and stir in 4 tbsp of butter
